*div1 type="summary"* *p*Samuel M. Williams to John Austin [March 20, 1831]. Acknowledging appointment as port officer at Brazoria.*/p* */div1*
*div1 type="body"*
*p*[March 20? 1831]*/p* *p*[To John Austin?]*/p*
*p**location_mentioned*Comisarios Departmt of Austin*/location_mentioned*— I have this day recd your official letter dated *date_mentioned n="03-15-1831">15th inst*/date_mentioned* informing me of your appointment as *person_mentioned*Port officer*/person_mentioned* in the place of*person_mentioned* Mr Dunlap*/person_mentioned* who at his own solicitation has been permitted to retire—- As an*person_mentioned* officer of the federation */person_mentioned*and charged with the executions of the maritime laws it is necessary, that, by all you should be respected in the official discharge of your duties, as well by *person_mentioned*citizens */person_mentioned*as by the *person_mentioned*local authorities*/person_mentioned*, because you represent the laws of the land, any disrespect offered to you as an officer is directed against the laws and not against you as an individual. Consequently I hope that there will be found *person_mentioned*citizens*/person_mentioned* enough within the limits of the jurisdiction, who not only respect their oaths of obedience and fidelity, but justly appreciate their own interest in the *location_mentioned*country */location_mentioned*and the benefits and favors they have recd from the govt to aid and assist you as an *person_mentioned*officer */person_mentioned*in the prompt discharge of your duties— I have—*/p*
*p*[S. M. Williams]*/p*
*/div1*
